source.citation: Kellogg, L.D. & Bettinger, P. 1994. Thinning Productivity and Cost for a Mechanized Cut-to-Length System in the Northwest Pacific Coast Region of the USA. Journal of Forest Engineering 5(2): 43-55.
notes: Study site: western Oregon second-growth thinning (marked vs. operator-select treatments).
Machines: Timberjack 2518 harvester with Koehring Waterous 762 head; FMG 910 forwarder.
Treatment (marked vs. unmarked) was not significant and was excluded from the regression.
Cost excludes profit/risk allowance; one-shift operation per PACE (1992).

delay_breakdown_notes: Total availability ≈ 82% and utilisation ≈ 69%; personal delays (43.9%) and repairs (34.6%) dominated.

regression.equation: vol_m3_per_pmh = 16.245 - 1.689 * mixed - 3.478 * pulp + 0.2707 * volume_per_load_m3 - 0.008 * distance_out_m - 0.0057 * travel_in_unit_m - 0.0039 * distance_in_m

variable_definitions.volume_per_load_m3: Product volume carried on the bunk (m^3)
variable_definitions.distance_out_m: Travel from landing to first loading point
variable_definitions.distance_in_m: Return travel from last loading location to landing

notes: Indicator variables: sawlog load (mixed=0, pulp=0), mixed load (mixed=1, pulp=0), pulp load (mixed=0, pulp=1).
Regression significance P < 0.10 for all variables.
Equation assumes direct transfer of mixed loads to trailers (no rehandling).
Mixed-load forwarding cost ≈ $6.80/m³; pulpwood forwarding cost ≈ 43% higher than sawlogs.

operational_notes: Two-pass technique (separate sawlog/pulp loads) outperformed single-pass when landing space was limited.
Average travel distances: distance_out ≈ 300 m, travel-in-unit varied 50-110 m depending on product (see Table 7).

variable_ranges.notes: Ranges pulled from Table 7; travel distances and volumes reflect the western Oregon thinning study domain (n=120).

cost_examples.notes: Derived from Table 8 using the regression equation and 1992 cost inputs (US$70.41/SMH).
